title: 107_s2458
content: Establishment of initiatives for predominantly Muslim countries. The Congress finds that negative opinions of the United States in predominantly Muslim countries are distorted by misinformation and propaganda, prejudicing US interests. To improve this image, programs promoting American society and values will be established by the Secretary of State. The Secretary of State will establish programs in countries with predominantly Muslim populations, including a journalism program for foreign journalists and postsecondary students, and a demonstration program to assist in establishing or upgrading public library systems. The program aims to improve public library systems, support education, and provide youth recreation centers. It includes training in library sciences and English language teaching opportunities. Sister city partnerships will be expanded to increase global cooperation at the community level. The Secretary will establish a program for youth ambassadors to visit the United States for cultural and educational activities, promoting global cooperation at the community level. The Secretary will establish a program to increase Fulbright and Hubert H. Humphrey Fellowships for individuals from predominantly Muslim countries to study, teach, or conduct research in the United States. Additionally, school-to-school linkages will be encouraged under the program. The Secretary aims to increase Hubert H. Humphrey Fellowships for candidates from predominantly Muslim countries. Programs will be carried out under specific acts. The Secretary will establish a database of American and foreign alumni of exchange programs to promote networking. Additionally, a report will be made on the inclusion of freedom and democracy advocates in exchange programs. The Secretary of State must submit a report to Congress within 90 days regarding the inclusion of freedom and democracy advocates in educational and cultural exchange programs. The report will detail the number of grants for exchange programs, measures taken to ensure advocates are considered in selection, and evaluate if programs are open to them. Additionally, a database of alumni will be established for networking purposes. SEC. 4. STATUTORY CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not allow visas or admission to the US for inadmissible aliens. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $35,000,000 is authorized for the Department of State for fiscal years 2003 and 2004. SEC. 6. SECRETARY DEFINED. "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of State.
